author: Ryan Sederquist
title: Battle Mountain boys basketball uses full-court press to jump start rally over Vail Mountain School
text:
News | Jan 16, 2025
Sawyer Willis helped Battle Mountain come back and defeat Vail Mountain School 42-39 on Tuesday night in Edwards.
Rex Keep/Courtesy photo It was all Gore Rangers in the first half of Tuesdayâ€™s rivalry game between the Vail Mountain and Battle Mountain boys basketball teams.
The second told a different story, though.
â€œIâ€™d describe it as a tale of two halves,â€ Vail Mountain coach Andrew Behrendt said after his team surrendered a 10-point first-half lead in losing to the Huskies 42-39 in Edwards. â€œI think we were the better team in the first half and they came storming back in the second â€” and it kind of came down to the wire.â€
â€œTo be able to come back from a deficit like that and collect themselves in the middle of the game â€” and rally back like that â€” Iâ€™m so happy for those boys,â€ Battle Mountain coach Rudy Ybarra said after his team completed the rally to protect its home court.
It was clear both teams wrote up good scouting reports going into the cross-county conflict, Ybarra said. The Huskies were forced into dribbling with their weak hands and struggled to find offensive flow throughout the first eight minutes as the Gore Rangers built a 10-6 lead.
Support Local Journalism Donate
â€œ(They) looked confident, collected and very calm on the defensive end and it helped them get more points on the offensive end, too,â€ Ybarra said.
Defense led to offense in the second quarter as well as Vail Mountain, ranked No. 13 in 2A, outscored its 5A opponent 16-10 in the second. Ybarra said he and his players went into the locker room looking for something in the toolbox to spark a run.
â€œWe all asked each other, â€˜what can we do differently to succeed here?,'â€ he said. â€œAnd we all agreed it was a full-court press weâ€™d been practicing.â€
The Gore Rangers managed the pressure well initially, even building their lead to 30-18 with 5:20 to go in the third quarter. But as fatigue set in, they struggled to initiate effective half-court offense coming out of the press break. Behrendt said he could tell his players felt â€œrushed and panicked a little bit.â€ To make matters worse, the Gore Rangers were just 2-for-10 from the free throw line in the second half. The Huskies capitalized, going on a 17-2 run to go up 35-32 with 2:30 remaining in the game.
â€œI knew they werenâ€™t going to give up after they gave up such a big lead,â€ Ybarra said of his mindset at that point. â€œSo we knew they had something in their bag. Andrew is such a creative guy.â€
With 1:37 left, Blake Roberts floated in two of his team-high nine points off a hard, right-handed drive from the wing to put the Huskies back up by three. Grant Iverson responded with a deep triple of his own 20 seconds later.
â€œIt was big,â€ Behrendt said of the clutch 3-pointer from Iverson, who had a game-high 12 points. â€œIt was important to tie it up to give ourselves a fighting chance.â€
Coming out of a timeout, Jackson Wansley gave a dribble hand off to Roberts, who charged off a double screen with his left hand. His drive ended with the ball deflecting off a Vail Mountain playerâ€™s foot. On the ensuing out of bounds play, Charlie Strauch found an uncovered Wansley in the corner. The junior drilled the a go-ahead 3-pointer in front of his bench. Ybarra said Wansley and Sawyer Willis were instrumental in securing the win through their leadership and on-court vision.
â€œThey communicated to their guys on how to stay focused and calm during the game,â€ the coach said. â€œAnd they just read the floor really well.â€
Charlie Vidal made things interesting, though, scoring with 38 seconds left to make it a one-point affair. But Wansley hit two free throws on the next possession and Vail Mountain couldnâ€™t convert a 3-pointer before the final buzzer.
Even though Behrendt identified areas for growth â€” â€œturnovers, finishing, handling pressure, stuff like that,â€ he said â€” Tuesdayâ€™s game was an improvement from last yearâ€™s trip to Edwards, a 60-26 loss.
â€œI think we are a very different team this year,â€ he added. â€œOur team chemistry is really strong this year; I think weâ€™re really deep. â€¦ I often tell these guys, for all the nitpicking, weâ€™re a good team that can fix some things to get better. And ultimately our goal is to be playing the best basketball at the end of the year.â€
Vail Mountain fell to 5-3 going into Fridayâ€™s home contest against De Beque. Battle Mountain improved to 3-4 and will look to keep the momentum going Thursday night at Delta. Having come back against Rifle and Meeker earlier this year, Ybarra said Tuesdayâ€™s win proved that basketball has two halves for a reason.
â€œThatâ€™s what itâ€™s there for: to show a different side of us and adjust so we can get a win,â€ he said. â€œSo I think the boys seeing that â€” weâ€™ve got more wins coming, just with that confidence.â€
Support Local Journalism Donate

author: Stephen Underwood
title: A CT regional market plans expansion in next year. â€˜Weâ€™ve really outgrown our kitchenâ€™
text:
A regional, third-generation,
family-owned grocery chain is planning to expand its operation with a new dedicated kitchen space that will meet demand for its prepared food items.
The
Highland Park Market grocery store, which has locations in Farmington, Glastonbury, and Manchester, recently bought the Bogner Quality Meats building at 349 Wetherell St. in Manchester.
The decades-old butcher shop, which has operated out of the location since the 1960s, will stay in the building for another year before moving to another spot in town.
Highland Park Market bought the nearly 20,000 square-foot building for $1.25 million in late August, according to the company.
Under the purchase-sales agreement, Bogner will continue to lease the building where it is currently located for another year until Highland Park Market takes over the space. The grocery store bought the building due to increased demand for its prepared food items.
â€œWeâ€™ve really outgrown our kitchen at our Manchester location,â€ said Molly Devanney, vice president of Highland Park Market.
â€œIf you were to look at our kitchen now, weâ€™ve got people on top of each other just trying to get all the orders done. So this will enable us a state of the art kitchen and allow our employees really more space to just do their jobs.â€
While plans remain tentative, Devanney said that the company would like to utilize the building primarily for storage and to prepare food that would then be distributed to its other retail locations.
In addition, a small meat counter and commissary is planned to sell grab-and-go prepared food items.
â€œWe also donâ€™t have a lot of freezer space in Manchester for refrigeration, so with the new building we were able to order extra product in for the holidays,â€ Devanney said. â€œWeâ€™re using the building just for storage right now until we can get in there and do some major renovation work to the property.â€
Over the next year, Devanney said, the company will begin to finalize plans for the space and start renovation work to transform the building. However, construction isnâ€™t planned for a while until the terms of the purchase-sales agreement are fully realized.
â€œWe want to be good landlords and take care of the people there now,â€ Devanney said.
â€œTheyâ€™re great people and we want to be very respectful of them. Weâ€™re not pushing them out and weâ€™re making sure to give them plenty of time,â€ Devanney said.
Bogner Quality Meats spokeswoman Beth Coviello said that the extra time will allow the company to find a permanent location and that both staff and ownership are grateful towards Highland Park Market for their hospitality.
â€œWe want to assure our customers that we arenâ€™t going away,â€ Coviello said. â€œWe will be staying in Manchester. While we have our eye on a new location, we still have to get permits and approval at the moment. So weâ€™re hoping to figure all that over the next few months.â€
Highland Park Market has been a staple in Manchester since opening in 1886, according to its website. Jack Devanney purchased the small market in 1958 and it has remained in the Devanney family since then. Today, the Devanney familyâ€™s third generation has taken over the day-to-day operations of the stores.
â€œOne of those things are grandfather did was really take the time to get to know his customers and give them the products that they want,â€ Devanney said.
â€œEverything we do involves people. Whether thatâ€™s taking care of our employees or our customers. We support the community that supports us. We love our customers and I think thatâ€™s what separates us from other grocery stores. We care about quality as well. But itâ€™s really about providing that customer service.â€
Stephen Underwood can be reached at sunderwood@courant.com.

author: Megan Grisham
title: â€˜Americaâ€™s Got Talentâ€™ Remembers Emily Gold As a â€œBright Young Soulâ€ In Special Tribute
text:
Emily Gold, a member of the Los Osos High School dance team, sadly passed away at 17-years-old on September 13. Gold and her dance team recently competed on Americaâ€™s Got Talent this season, making it to the quarterfinals before being eliminated.
Emily Gold tragically passed away from injuries after jumping from an overpass, according to the California Highway Patrol . Her death has been ruled a suicide.
Emily Goldâ€™s Dance Team and Coach Pay Tribute to Her Impact On and Off The Stage In a statement made to Instagram, the Los Osos dance team remembered Gold for her â€œkindness, compassion and the most humble heart.â€
â€œShe will be remembered as a leader, role model, friend, and sister to her teammates,â€ the statement read. â€œOur sweet sweet Emily. We love you endlessly and miss you more than word can ever express. Everything we do is for you, our beautiful Angel.â€
View this post on Instagram A post shared by LOHS Varsity DanceðŸ’™ðŸ’› (@lohsvarsitydance)
Goldâ€™s dance coach, Rachel Muego, who guided the team through their journey on Americaâ€™s Got Talent , also shared a heartfelt tribute to Emily . In her statement, Muego shared how Goldâ€™s dedication and commitment to the team made them stronger.
â€œThank you Em for believing and supporting this team since day 1,â€ she wrote. â€œYou put your heart and soul into everything we did , big or small, and valued this team no matter what. Through the ups and downs you never ever stopped believing in us.â€
The statement went on to acknowledge Goldâ€™s positivity and the light she brought to everyone around her.
â€œAll I keep hearing in my head is your voice, seeing your beautiful smile, hearing your laugh and all of the positive words youâ€™d bring to us daily. You lit up all of our lives and I know youâ€™re going to keep doing just that, shining for us and being that peace and hope that we all need. Em I miss you so much and from the bottom of my heart THANK YOU.â€
Americaâ€™s Got Talent Remembers Emily Gold In a Touching Message In a Facebook post made a few days after Emily Goldâ€™s Passing, Americaâ€™s Got Talent shared their condolences to her family and loved ones. AGT also remembered her as a â€œbright young soulâ€ during her time on the show.
â€œThe AGT Family sends out our heartfelt condolences to the family, friends and team members of Emily Gold,â€ â€˜AGTâ€™ wrote. â€œShe was a bright young soul and will be deeply missed.â€
The statement was accompanied by a photo of Emily posing in front of a backdrop and a sign that read â€œAGT,â€ seemingly taken before one of her performances on the show.
Facebook/AGT To support Emily Goldâ€™s family during this difficult time, a GoFundMe has been created to help with expenses. If youâ€™d like to donate, click HERE .
If you or someone you know is considering suicide, please contact the 988 Suicide and Crisis Lifeline by dialing or texting 988 or visit 988lifeline.org .

author: Ishara S. KODIKARA
title: Official estimates suggest that about a third of all crops in Sri Lanka are eaten or destroyed by wild animals | | kilgorenewsherald.com
text:
Official estimates suggest that about a third of all crops in Sri Lanka are eaten or destroyed by wild animals
- Ishara S. KODIKARA
- Updated
Tags
As featured on
Sri Lanka will launch a nationwide census of nuisance wildlife, including monkeys and peacocks, as part of an effort to tackle the increasing threat to agriculture, the government said Wednesday.

author: Mark Heyka NonStop Local Meteorologist
title: Trick-or-treaters in Bozeman and Missoula face evening rain showers | Montana Local Weather | montanarightnow.com
text: MONTANA - Today, temperatures were in the 30s to the west, the 40s in central Montana, and in the 50s to the east. Radar showed rain and snow, mainly across western Montana. Winds were light to the west but were gustier in central and eastern areas. Trick or treaters may get doused with a little rain this evening from the Missoula area to Bozeman. However, it should be dry in central and northeast areas. A cold front has brought colder weather to western Montana along with some rain and snow, which will end early tonight. Sunny and mild skies are forecasted to return to central and east Montana on Friday with cloudy skies to west. Another storm system will bring rain and snow this weekend to Missoula and Kalispell to the Helena, Butte and Bozeman areas. A winter weather advisory will be in place through Friday for the mountains of Madison and Gallatin Counties at elevations above 6000 feet, where one to nine inches of snow are possible. Lows tonight will range in the upper 10s and 20s with highs tomorrow ranging in the mid 40s to mid 50s. Mild temperatures are expected this weekend in central and eastern areas, but it will be a bit chilly in the west. Highs will range from the 40s to the west and into the 50s to the east.

author: AFP
title: Campaigners fear spike in hate speech as Meta lifts restrictions | National | themercury.com
text:
Tech giant Meta has rolled back restrictions around topics such as gender and sexual identity, a sweeping move advocacy groups fear will fuel hate speech.
The change coincides with the company's shock announcement on Tuesday that it was ending its third-party fact-checking program in the United States and adopting a crowd-sourced model to police misinformation similar to the Elon Musk-owned X.
The latest version of Meta's community guidelines said its platforms -- which include Facebook and Instagram -- would now permit users to accuse people of "mental illness or abnormality" based on their gender or sexual orientation.
The updated version also struck out previous restrictions on referring to women as "household objects or property," Black people as "farm equipment" and transgender or non-binary people as "it."
"We're getting rid of a number of restrictions on topics like immigration, gender identity and gender that are the subject of frequent political discourse and debate," Joel Kaplan, Meta's chief global affairs officer, wrote in a blog post.
"It's not right that things can be said on TV or the floor of Congress, but not on our platforms."
But advocacy groups quickly voiced concern that the policy shift threatened the safety of marginalized communities.
"Removal of fact-checking programs and industry-standard hate speech policies make Meta's platforms unsafe places," said Sarah Kate Ellis, president of the advocacy group GLAAD.
"Without these necessary hate speech and other policies, Meta is giving the green light for people to target LGBTQ people, women, immigrants, and other marginalized groups with violence, vitriol, and dehumanizing narratives."
Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg, in a video announcing the changes, claimed the previous restrictions on immigration and gender were "just out of touch with mainstream discourse."
"What started as a movement to be more inclusive has increasingly been used to shut down opinions and shut out people with different ideas, and it has gone too far," Zuckerberg said.
The move comes just weeks before Donald Trump returns to the White House with his Republican Party also back in control of Congress after fiercely attacking social media speech restrictions during the election campaign.
Gender identity issues were also a key line of attack by Trump and Republicans against their Democratic opponents.
After the move was announced on Tuesday, CyberWell, a nonprofit focused on combating online antisemitism, denounced the "systematic lowering of the bar" by Meta on policies against hate speech and harassment.
"This change particularly undermines the safety of all marginalized communities," CyberWell executive director Tal-Or Cohen Montemayor said in a statement.
bur-ac/des
Originally published on doc.afp.com , part of the BLOX Digital Content Exchange .

author: Li_Dan
title: Baidu Revenue Beats as AI Cloud Offsets Sluggish Online Marketing
text:
TMTPOST -- The American depositary receipts (ADRs) of Baidu, Inc. slumped 5.9% to their two-month low on Thursday even though artificial intelligence (AI) technology helped Chinaâ€™s top search engine operator report better-than-expected sales.
Baidu said its revenue for three months ended September 30, 2024 came in RMB33.56 billion (US$4.6 billion). That represented a year-over-year (YoY) decrease of 3%, the biggest yearly drop in more than two years, but still topping analystsâ€™ projection of RMB33.53 billion. Decline in the top line accelerated as the previous quarter saw Baidu revenue edged down about 0.4% from a year ago, the companyâ€™s first YoY decline since the third quarter of 2022.
Baiduâ€™s quarterly bottom line first missed Wall Street anticipation this year, highlighting how Chinaâ€™s economic slowdown dragged companies as its key advertisers span indutries from property devlopers to automakers. Net income for the third quarter jumped 14% YoY to RMB7.63 billion, or US$1.09 billion, less than analysts expected US$857.17 millon. On non-GAAP basis, adjusted net income dipped 19% YoY to RMB5.89 billion, compared with a 8% YoY fall three months earlier. Adjusted earnings per American depositary share (ADS) was RMB16.6 with a 19% YoY decrease, versus analysts projected RMB17.73. Adjusted operating income dropped 8% YoY to RMB7.01 billion, compared with a 2% YoY increase for the previous quarter. That was still better than projection of RMB6.36 billion.
Baidu Core, which accounts for nearly 79% of overall revenue for the third quarter, stagnated for the September quarter. The segment generated RMB26.52 billion with almost no growth compared with a year earlier. The mainstay segment decelerated as it had eked out a 1% YoY gain for the second quarter, down from a quarterly growth rate of 4% in the start of this year. Net income of Baidu Core added 17% YoY to RMB7.54 billion, while non-GAAP adjusted net income fell 18% YoY to RMB5.68 billion.
Online marketing, a major part of Baidu Core, brought RMB18.8 billion with a 4% YoY decrease, versus a 2% drop from April to June. Non-online marketing revenue was RMB7.7 billion with a 12% YoY gain, mainly driven by AI Cloud business. That division accelerated from a 10% increase for the previous quarter.
â€œBaidu Core's flattish third quarter top line reflected the ongoing weakness in our online marketing business, offset by the growth of our AI Cloud business. Our strong AI capabilities are gaining broader market recognition, as evidenced by increasing adoption of Ernie,â€ Baidu CEO RObin Li said.
For the third quarter, Baidu expanded the Ernie family with two enhanced lightweight models, Speed Pro and Lite Pro. Baiduâ€™s flagship model, ERNIE 4.0 Turbo, has achieved notable improvements in inference efficiency, with throughput increasing by 48% compared to its debut in June. Thanks to Erine's enhanced capabilities, wide-ranging applications, and improved cost efficiencies, Baidu has seen a substantial increase in API calls, Li said. He noted Ernie handled approximately 1.5 billion API calls daily in November, a significant jump from 600 million in August. Meanwhile, over 1.7 trillion tokens were generated on a daily basis.
Li underscore momentum of AI Cloud. Revenue from AI Cloud reached RMB4.9 billion for the third quarter, maintaining double-digit YoY increase at 11% while sustaining non-GAAP operating profitability. Generative AI-related revenue maintained strong growth momentum and remained a key growth driver, accounting for about 11% of Baiduâ€™s total AI Cloud revenue in the third quarter, up from 9% in the preceding quarter, Li said. He commemted that this trend reflected increasing recognition of Ernie's value among enterprise customers.
Apollo Go, Baidu's autonomous ride-hailing service, provided 988,000 rides in the third quarter, up 20% YoY. As of October 28, the cumulative rides provided to the public by Apollo Go surpassed 8 million. During the third quarter, rides provided by Apollo Go's fully driverless vehicles accounted for over 70% of total rides nationwide. The proportion of fully driverless rides further increased to 80% in October.
â€œApollo Go continues to lead the global autonomous ride-hailing market, hitting another milestone with our sixth-generation autonomous vehicle now operating on public roads across multiple cities in China,â€ Li said.â€Despite the near-term pressures, we remain steadfast in our AI-focused strategy and are confident in our long-term trajectory. As we further scale AI, we are emboldened to find how it can drive innovations and create value for consumers, enterprises and society at large.â€
